page.title: 14Plant and Animal Life
page.content: "The river up to the Furnace Bridge is tidal, which means that you have sea water life up to the bridge. The river is often coloured due to industrial pollution". Smaller (plants) under the trees and in the open spaces included: daffodils, hundreds of daisies, lots of buttercups, small clumps of bluebells dotted on the river banks, ferns, wild garlic with small white flowers growing on them, lots of purpley blue foxgloves. In Spring time there are lots of celandines. There are clover, dog roses, red-campion and a few march marigolds. There are patches of gorse, bracken, thistle, nettles, dock, butter - bur, primrose and blackberry. A lot of animals live by the riverside: fox, weasles, water voles, mice rabbits, moles, hedgehogs, red squirrels, and badgers.
